Kuroda also suggested they can raise bond purchases further if required and suggested it is better to act quickly even if the virus impact is temporary. (Newswires)

Other News BoK cut key base rate by 50bps to 0.75% in an emergency move and said it will lower borrowing costs on lending programmes for companies. (Newswires)

South Korean Vice Finance Minister Kim said cannot rule out possibility of economic and financial crises, while Kim reiterated they will take market stabilization measures in a timely manner. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

G7 leaders said stepping up their COVID-19 response is their foremost priority and will make efforts to increase the availability of medical equipment where it is most needed. Furthermore, they are mobilising the full range of instruments, including monetary and fiscal measures, while they ask central banks to continue to coordinate necessary monetary measures and finance ministers will coordinate on a weekly basis on the implementation of stimulus measures and other steps that could be taken. (Newswires)

IMF said it is ready to mobilize USD 1trln loan capacity to fight COVID-19 and that fiscal stimulus will be necessary to prevent long-lasting economic damage such as raised paid sick leave and targeted tax relief. (Newswires)

White House recommended 15-day nationwide guidelines to slow spread of virus and avoiding social gatherings, while the affected states should close schools and surrounding areas. (Newswires)

US Senate may want to amend the House virus Bill package and it might not pass immediately according to Politico, while there were separate reports that US Senate Democratic leader Schumer is to propose legislation for at least USD 750bln to address the coronavirus outbreak and support the economy. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau announced that Canada will close its borders to non-citizens and non-residents although it won't apply to commerce or trade, and he will not rule out any measure to keep Canadians safe. (Newswires)

EU Commission President von der Leyen said the EU is to introduce temporary restrictions on non-essential travel to EU for 30 days and will not hesitate to take further measures as the situation evolves. In related news, Eurogroup said it has thus far committed to providing liquidity facilities amounting to at least 10% of GDP and these figures could be much larger going forward, while the European Investment Bank stated the EU could muster between EUR 28bln-40bln immediately to support firms against the backdrop of the virus. (Newswires)

Italy’s total coronavirus cases rose to 27980 (Prev. 24747) and the death toll increased to 2158 (Prev. 1809), while Italy approved decree worth EUR 25bln to aid the economy amid the virus outbreak. (Newswires)

UK number of coronavirus cases rose to 1,543 on Monday (from 1,372 on Sunday)

UK PM Johnson said we need to further on COVID-19 advice and looks as though UK is approaching the fast growth part of the virus spread, while he suggested that cases could double every five days without drastic action. Furthermore, he asked individuals who self-isolate to stay as such for 14 days (Prev. 7 days) and for individuals to work from home where possible, while he urged against mass gatherings. (Newswires)

UK Government Chief Scientific Advisor Vallance said other possible measures such as closing schools may be necessary. (Newswires)

France President Macron said Shengen area borders in France will be shut from tomorrow midday in coordination with EU nations,

German Finance Minister Scholz said the country will counter the economic impact of the coronavirus "with full force" and that fiscal measures to counter the virus will impact federal budget plans from 2021-24, while Germany will provide additional funds needed to tackle the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Switzerland said border checks will be introduced with Germany, France and Austria, while it noted only Swiss citizens, residents and business travellers can enter the country. (Newswires)

Riksbank to boost asset purchases and take measures to facilitate credit supply, while it will support economic developments and avoid credit supply issues. Riksbank added it will increase loans to banks on favourable terms and will buy SEK 300bln of bonds. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the Administration not currently considering nationwide lockdown but looking at certain regions and noted the US may extend sick leave to companies with more than 500 people, while he suggested the worst of the virus outbreak could be over by July/August, perhaps later. (Newswires 

 

ASIA-PAC

BoK cut key base rate by 50bps to 0.75% in an emergency move and said it will lower borrowing costs on lending programmes for companies. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

BoE Governor Bailey said you will see prompt action from the BoE again when it is needed and will see the effect of swap lines in the coming days, while he added that the move by central banks is a strong signal of coordination and is very keen to ensure long-term economic damage is minimized. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES 

US could start purchasing crude in the next two weeks to top up its strategic reserve and could purchase 77mln barrels of US-produced oil. (Newswires)

Saudi Aramco CEO said we are currently assessing raising oil production capacity to 13mln BPD and will be producing at our maximum oil production capacity, while he added that the Co. is very conformable with oil at USD 30/bbl. (Newswires)

OPEC/OPEC+ JTC meeting planned for March 18th in Vienna has been cancelled, according to sources. (Newswires) 

 

US

NEC Director Kudlow the US is going to be very challenged with the economy but noted there is more than USD 800bln of fiscal measures, including a possible payroll tax holiday that could or have been put in place to support the US. Furthermore, Kudlow said the administration would consider sending cash to households as a form of short-term relief and is thinking about 100% expensing companies moving back to the US from China and elsewhere. (Newswires/Fox)

White House Trade Advisor Navarro asked Congress to consider payroll tax cut through 2020-end, bringing Executive Order to US President Trump on supply chain. (CNBC)

White House is drafting a financial assistance package for airlines (AAL, UAL, DAL) that is expected to include direct help, loans and tax relief according to sources, while US President Trump later commented the US will back the airlines 100% and has told airlines it will help them and backstop the airlines (Newswires)

There are reportedly active discussions within the Trump administration to encourage a possible “curfew” across the nation in which non-essential businesses would have to close by a certain time each night, according to CNN's Sciutto. (Twitter) 

 

MARKET RECAP

US stocks were hammered again on Monday, with the circuit breaker tripped after about a minute of trading. That theme continued throughout the session, and in later trade, the VIX tested all-time highs. The Fed's measures taken over the weekend again highlight how bad the situation is getting, dragging rates lower, while grim China activity data was also reported - similar was seen in the NY Fed survey. Banks have been cutting its estimate of US GDP growth, and sees the size of the economy shrinking by 5% in Q2, and later President Trump said US "may be" heading into a recession. Amid COVID-19, multiple companies announced closures of stores and operations, where retailers such as Nike (NKE), Lululemon (LULU), Under Armour (UAA) and Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) are temporarily closing some of its stores across America. Nike (NKE) however, is expanding its closures to Western Europe, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) announced it is closing all of its stores outside of China for the next two weeks. Multiple casino operators are suspending operations, particularly in Illinois, Michigan and Ohio, while Wynn Resorts (WYNN) is temporarily halting operations at its Las Vegas resort. Cruise liners (CCL, RCL, NCLH) are also halting operations and Airlines (AAL, UAL, DAL, LUV) are preparing for further disruption. Elsewhere, the FAA is reportedly considering enhanced inspections on Boeing (BA) 737 jets after an inflight incident on a Southwestern Airlines (LUV) plane saw a 12-inch rupture in the aluminium skin of the plane. SPX -11.99% at 2386, NDX -12.19% at 7020, DJI -12.94% at 20,186.

The NY Fed’s Desk’s USD 500bln 30-day term operation and USD 175bln o/n op were both undersubscribed, the former seeing all USD 18.45bln bids accepted (500bln offered) and the latter seeing all USD 129.60bln bids accepted (175bln offered). However, despite more liquidity offered by the Fed, signs of stress remained in funding markets, as evidenced by FRA-OIS widening on the day, as well as the overnight GC rate spiking to 2.0%. The further tightening led the Fed to announce an additional overnight repo operation later on Monday, offering USD 500bln, seeing the rate move lower again on announcement, although still elevated significantly above the Fed’s new 0-0.25% target range. However, the later operation saw all USD 19.40bln bids accepted while the GC rate came back close to the FFR. Meanwhile, the Desk also carried out its ramped-up Treasury and MBS purchases across the curve – USD 40bln in Treasuries and USD 7.6bln in MBS on Monday. T-Notes (H0) settled 2 points and 8+ ticks higher at 138-02.

BuzzFeed's Political Editor Wickham tweets UK only realised "in the last few days" that attempts to "mitigate" the coronavirus pandemic would not work, and that it needed to shift to a strategy to "suppress" according to a report by a team of experts
content: adds it found from new data that mitigation would "likely result in hundreds of thousands of deaths and health systems (most notably intensive care units) being overwhelmed many times over", citing the Imperial College COVID-19 Response Team which has been advising SAGE.

subject: US Market Wrap - 16th March 2020: Fed aggressive easing fails to stem aggressive liquidations
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Crude down, Dollar up/flat.
  • REAR VIEW: Fed cuts to ZLB and ramps liquidity offerings; repo rate spike sees NY Fed step in; further APAC emergency rate cuts; travel restrictions tighten; IMF flexes USD 1trln loan availability 
  • COMING UP: Data: UK Labour Market. German ZEW Survey, US Retail Sales & IP, Weekly Private Crude Inventories, Japanese Trade Balance. Event: RBA Minutes (Mar), Swiss SECO Forecasts, EZ Finance Minister Monthly Meeting. Speakers: ECB’s de Guindos, RBA Assistance Governor Ellis. Supply: UK.

* MARKET WRAP: US stocks were hammered again on Monday, with the circuit breaker tripped after about a minute of trading. That theme continued throughout the session, and in later trade, the VIX tested all-time highs. The Fed's measures taken over the weekend again highlight how bad the situation is getting, dragging rates lower, while grim China activity data was also reported - similar was seen in the NY Fed survey. Banks have been cutting its estimate of US GDP growth, and sees the size of the economy shrinking by 5% in Q2, and later President Trump said US "may be" heading into a recession. US cases of the virus have risen over 3,500 from under 1,700 at the previous update; the White House has recommended 15-day guidelines (details below). Meanwhile, the Senate is to consider the House virus bill, and Senator Schumer suggested Senators could request USD 750bln package to combat the spread.

* FED: FOMC cut the Fed Funds Rate 100bps to 0.00%-0.25% via 9-1 vote (Mester dissented preferring a 50bps cut) and the Fed launched USD 700bln QE program in which it will increase Treasury purchases by at least USD 500bln and raise MBS purchases by USD 200bln. Fed expects target interest rates will remain in this range until economy has weathered recent events and is on track to meet inflation and employment targets, while it is reducing requirement ratio to 0% effective March 26th. Fed Chair Powell said that the emergency FOMC meeting was in lieu of meeting on March 17th-18th. Furthermore, Powell the Fed doesn't see negative rates as appropriate policy response in the US and he is willing to be patient in assessing when to raise rates back from near-zero. Fed, BoJ, BoE, Bank of Canada, ECB and SNB have agreed to lower pricing on standing US Dollar liquidity swaps by 25bps and that central banks will offer US Dollar swaps with 84-day maturities in addition to 1-week operations.

* TREASURIES: The NY Fed’s Desk’s USD 500bln 30-day term operation and USD 175bln o/n op were both undersubscribed, the former seeing all USD 18.45bln bids accepted (500bln offered) and the latter seeing all USD 129.60bln bids accepted (175bln offered). However, despite more liquidity offered by the Fed, signs of stress remained in funding markets, as evidenced by FRA-OIS widening on the day, as well as the overnight GC rate spiking to 2.0%. The further tightening led the Fed to announce an additional overnight repo operation later on Monday, offering USD 500bln, seeing the rate move lower again on announcement, although still elevated significantly above the Fed’s new 0-0.25% target range. However, the later operation saw all USD 19.40bln bids accepted while the GC rate came back close to the FFR. Meanwhile, the Desk also carried out its ramped-up Treasury and MBS purchases across the curve – USD 40bln in Treasuries and USD 7.6bln in MBS on Monday. T-Notes (H0) settled 2 points and 8+ ticks higher at 138-02.

* MARKET CLOSURES: There has been some speculation that markets could be closed due to the information uncertainty creating choppy trading conditions. Additionally, some draw attention to the unforeseen credit events that could spur if valuations continue to tumble, triggering credit facility covenants. However, SEC Chair said on Monday that markets should stay open despite intense volatility, and that the SEC was closely monitoring markets and was working with exchanges and market infrastructure providers to ensure they could continue to function. Note that equity indices nearly reached their 13% limit down shortly after the US cash equity open on Monday This sentiment was also echoed by NYSE President too.

* MONETARY POLICY: RBNZ lowered the OCR by 75bps to 0.25% in an emergency meeting and stated that the OCR is to remain at 0.25% for at least a year, while it delayed higher capital requirements for banks and stated that if more stimulus is required, the preference is large scale government bond purchases instead of another rate cut. BoJ held an emergency monetary policy meeting in which it kept short-term rates at -0.10% and maintained long-term yield target at 0%, but raised purchases of ETFs and J-REITS. BoJ announced additional JPY 100bln JGB purchases. RBA said it is to conduct 1-month and 3-month operations until further notice, while it will conduct 6-month operations or longer at least weekly. Furthermore, the RBA later said it added AUD 5.9bln to banking system through market repo operations, while it is ready to purchase Australia government bonds and will announce further policy steps on Thursday. HKMA lowered its base rate by 64bps to 0.86% and announced that the countercyclical buffer is to be lowered to 1% from 2% with immediate effect. BoK cuts key base rate by 50bps to 0.75% in an emergency move. Later, Riksbank said it will boost asset purchases and take measures to facilitate credit supply; will support economic developments and avoid credit supply issues; Will increase loans to banks on favourable terms, will buy SEK 300bln of bonds, and says it will take additional measures if necessary; Riksbank notes there will be negative impacts on activity from COVID, but says it is uncertain how deep.

* US MEASURES: On the weekend, US House voted 363-40 to pass bill to make coronavirus testing free and require paid sick leave for those impacted by the coronavirus outbreak; Senate will reconvene on Monday to consider that bill. Over the weekend, the CDC also recommended that Americans cancel or postpone gatherings of 50 or more people for the next eight weeks. NEC Director Kudlow the US is considering sending cash to households as short-term relief. Kudlow also said there is more than USD 800bln of fiscal measures available, including a possible payroll tax holiday, that could or have been put in place to support the US. Kudlow also said that the Administration is mulling 100% expensing companies moving back to the US from China and elsewhere; the story is in keeping with remarks from White House Navarro said he was bringing an executive order to US President Trump which would lower the dependency on foreign countries for medicines. Elsewhere, White House is drafting a financial assistance package for airlines that is expected to include direct help, loans, and tax relief, sources report. Note that US Senate Minority Leader Schumer proposed a USD 750bln COVID-19 package later on Monday. Elsewhere, US CDC says 53 states have reported cases as of Sunday 4pm, versus 47 on Saturday; cases now at 3536 vs 1678. White House recommends 15-day nationwide guidelines to slow spread of virus; recommends avoiding social gatherings, says affected states should close schools and surrounding areas

* IMF MEASURES: IMF said it is ready to mobilize USD 1trln loan capacity to fight COVID-19, writing that fiscal stimulus will be necessary to prevent long-lasting economic damage, such as raised paid sick leave and targeted tax relief. The institution said it has received interest from about 20 more countries for ongoing loan programmes, in addition to 40 existing programmes totalling USD 200bln, and said that central bank swap lines to EM countries could be needed. The IMD said forex interventions and capital flow management measures can usefully complement monetary policy actions, and banks should use their capital and liquidity buffers as well as renegotiate loan terms for stressed borrowers. The Catastrophe Containment and Relief Trust for the poorest countries has about USD 400mln available for potential debt relief, looking to raise it to USD 1bln.

* EU MEASURES: The EU could immediately offer EUR 28-40bln to support SMEs in the region who have been hit by coronavirus, according to a letter from the European Investment Bank to EU finance ministers. Separately, the EU now thinks the economy will shrink 1.0% this year (previously it had pencilled in a RISE of 1.4% in 2020); earlier, Germany's Finance Ministry said it expects GDP to shrink in 2020, and expects to see the impact of COVID-19 on tax revenues and state spending. German Finance Minister Scholz says the country will counter the economic impact of the coronavirus "with full force", says fiscal measures to counter the virus will impact federal budget plans from 2021-24; Germany ready to take on new debt if necessary to combat the virus, according to economy minister Altmaier. France President Macron says all companies must take steps to work from home; says citizens should work from home and only leave for essential duties; will step up measures to limit peoples' movements. Macron also said Shengen area borders in France will be shut from tomorrow midday, in coordination with EU nations; he also said gas, electricity, water bills and rent will be suspended; French companies loans will benefit from state guarantee worth a total 300bln euros. Later, Eurozone finance ministers agreed to fiscal boost of 1%/GDP to combat COVID, and the Eurogroup said it has thus far committed to providing liquidity facilities amounting to at least 10% of GDP - these figures could be much larger going forward.

* TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS: The European Commission proposed a 30-day ban on incoming travel for foreigners. "The less travel, the more we can contain the virus. Therefore ... I propose to the heads of state and government to introduce temporary restriction on non-essential travel to the EU," EC Chief von der Leyen said, adding "these travel restrictions should be in place for an initial period of 30 days, but can be prolonged as necessary." There would be exclusions for long-term EU residents, family of EU nationals, as well as doctors and researchers working on containing the virus. Meanwhile Canadian President Trudeau declared that Canada would close its borders to non-citizens and non-residents, although the ban won’t apply to commerce or trade.

* WTI (J0) SETTLES USD 3.03 LOWER AT USD 28.70/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLES USD 3.80 LOWER AT USD 30.05/BBL: Energy markets were offered heavily to kick off the week as oil prices broke to levels not seen since the 2016 trough. Negative sentiment was evident in both oil futures and the further losses in global equity markets. Additionally, the outlook remains dismal on the supply side of the market too, as Russia and Saudi ramp-up production in their new price war. Saudi Aramco said on Monday it would be producing at its maximum capacity and is currently looking at raising its output to 13mln BPD; the oil behemoth added that it is very comfortable with oil at USD 30/bbl. Furthermore, the OPEC/OPEC+ JTC meeting planned for March 18th in Vienna has reportedly been cancelled, diminishing hopes of potential coordination even at the lower level. Following the Trump administration announcing on Friday it would be purchasing oil via the SPR, on Monday it was reported the US could start purchasing crude in the next two weeks, specifically that 77mln barrels of US-produced oil could be purchased, without any mention of purchasing foreign grades. Goldman Sachs said the SPR purchases could raise the equilibrium price where global oil market rebalances by USD 2/bbl, adding that the purchases could be insufficient to reverse the increasingly likely risk Brent declines beneath Q2-Q3 USD 30/bbl forecast, however. IHS Markit said the oil markets are facing a possible build-up of the most extreme oil supply surplus ever recorded, saying US production could decline between 2-4mln BPD over the next 18-months, with the surplus potentially growing to 800mln-1.3bln barrels in the first half of 2020 – the market will increasingly expect the support from the SPR if/as these forecasts become realized.

* GEOPOLITICS: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo warned Iraq that the US would continue to take self-defence measures if it is attacked; the statement followed the weekend rocket attack on an Iraqi base that houses US troops.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -11.99% at 2386, NDX -12.19% at 7020, DJI -12.94% at 20,186. Sectors: consumer staples -6.66%, telecoms -6.82%, health care -9.32%, basic materials -10.7%, cyclicals -10.83%, industrials -11.09%, utilities -11.58%, energy -12.92%, tech -13.09%, financials -13.23%. 

* US BANKS: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the banking system in the US "can handle this" in wake of the Federal reserve's emergency action. Mnuchin believes that the Fed is ahead of issues, noting nobody has to pull money out of banks. The goal is not to bail out companies and it aims to ensure businesses have liquidity, Mnuchin said, and stated there will be a surge of demand for stocks once the threat of coronavirus is gone.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Amid COVID-19, multiple companies announced closures of stores and operations, where retailers such as Nike (NKE), Lululemon (LULU), Under Armour (UAA) and Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) are temporarily closing some of its stores across America. Nike (NKE) however, is expanding its closures to Western Europe, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) announced it is closing all of its stores outside of China for the next two weeks. Multiple casino operators are suspending operations, particularly in Illinois, Michigan and Ohio, while Wynn Resorts (WYNN) is temporarily halting operations at its Las Vegas resort. Cruise liners (CCL, RCL, NCLH) are also halting operations and Airlines (AAL, UAL, DAL, LUV) are preparing for further disruption. Elsewhere, the FAA is reportedly considering enhanced inspections on Boeing (BA) 737 jets after an inflight incident on a Southwestern Airlines (LUV) plane saw a 12-inch rupture in the aluminium skin of the plane. Apple (AAPL) is to be fined EUR 1.2bln over anti-competitive behaviour by French authorities. Microsoft (MSFT) co-founder Bill Gates stepped down from the board, while also stepping down from the Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) board. On the credit front, Micron (MU) announced it is to draw down USD 2.5bln through its revolving credit facility, and Carnival (CCL) is to borrow USD 3bln under a facility agreement for six months, as part of the growing cohort of US corporates drawing on funding markets.

analysis_details: • Energy markets were offered heavily to kick off the week as oil prices broke to levels not seen since the 2016 trough. Negative sentiment was evident in both oil futures and the further losses in global equity markets. Additionally, the outlook remains dismal on the supply side of the market too, as Russia and Saudi ramp-up production in their new price war. Saudi Aramco said on Monday it would be producing at its maximum capacity and is currently looking at raising its output to 13mln BPD; the oil behemoth added that it is very comfortable with oil at USD 30/bbl. Furthermore, the OPEC/OPEC+ JTC meeting planned for March 18th in Vienna has reportedly been cancelled, diminishing hopes of potential coordination even at the lower level. Following the Trump administration announcing on Friday it would be purchasing oil via the SPR, on Monday it was reported the US could start purchasing crude in the next two weeks, specifically that 77mln barrels of US-produced oil could be purchased, without any mention of purchasing foreign grades. Goldman Sachs said the SPR purchases could raise the equilibrium price where global oil market rebalances by USD 2/bbl, adding that the purchases could be insufficient to reverse the increasingly likely risk Brent declines beneath Q2-Q3 USD 30/bbl forecast, however. IHS Markit said the oil markets are facing a possible build-up of the most extreme oil supply surplus ever recorded, saying US production could decline between 2-4mln BPD over the next 18-months, with the surplus potentially growing to 800mln-1.3bln barrels in the first half of 2020 – the market will increasingly expect the support from the SPR if/as these forecasts become realized.

Daily FX Wrap: another Monday mauling for risk, but mood improves incrementally
content:
JPY/CAD/AUD

The Yen is still outperforming on safe-haven grounds as another round of global Central Bank monetary easing (including the BoJ) and fiscal support from Governments fails to convince markets that China’s COVID-19 pandemic won’t wreak more havoc before the worst is over. However, sentiment has gradually improved since the US open and the latest 7% circuit breaks for the main Wall Street benchmarks forced a pause in trade and subsequent consolidation. Hence, Usd/Jpy is back above 106.00 within 105.16-107.91 parameters, while the Loonie and Aussie have rebounded from worst levels sub-0.6100 and close to 1.4000 again vs their US counterpart, even though the DXY has pared some of its post-Fed rate cut (100 bp) and QE (Usd700 bn) declines. In fact, the index bounced just over a full point at one stage between 97.446-98.473 extremes as US Treasuries yields bottomed and the curve re-steepened.

CHF/GBP/NZD/EUR

All now firmer against the Greenback, albeit with the Franc losing momentum after a test of resistance around 0.9400 and the Pound unable to sustain gains much beyond 1.2400 in early EU trade. Indeed, Cable subsequently slumped towards 1.2200 in contrast to Nzd/Usd that has regrouped after a slide through 0.5950 in wake of the RBNZ’s 75 bp OCR ease to approach 0.6100, as Aud/Nzd crosses 1.0050 following latest RBA repo and bank liquidity projections. The latter pairing  may be gearing up for something bigger from the RBA this Thursday after forward guidance overnight flagged the potential for QE given that rates are already at the lower bound. Back to Europe, Eur/Usd breached 1.1200 when the Buck was succumbing to broad selling pressure, but single currency has also conceded ground even though Eurozone bonds are sharply underperforming post-ECB and amidst more fiscal stimulus into today’s Eurogroup meeting.

SCANDI/EM 

Not much respite for the forlorn Norwegian Crown after hitting fresh record lows vs the Euro circa 11.5865, but a rebound in crude prices following reports that the US could top up its SPR by some 75-77 mn brls has seen the cross drift back down through 11.5000. Conversely, dovish talk and actual action from the likes of the NBH and CNB respectively (latter lowering rates by ½ point and keeping the door ajar for more) merely piled more pressure on the Forint and Koruna. Elsewhere, other oil and commodity-linked currencies were also hit hard, like the Rub, Zar, Mxn, while the Brl was also cautious in the run up to the BCB policy meeting on Wednesday. On that note, the SARB, CBR and CBRT are also all scheduled to deliver rate decisions this week, assuming no emergency or pre-meeting moves if course.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 16th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Of note for Airlines (LUV, DAL, UAL), operators are preparing for further flight reductions after US President Trump announced the travel ban has been extended to the UK and Ireland. Meanwhile, LUV announced it is seriously considering reducing flights in the short term and United Airlines (UAL) announced it is now expecting March revenue to be down USD 1.5bln Y/Y.
  • Of note for Retailers (UAA, NKE, ANF, WMT, GPS, LULU) all announced they are to temporarily close stores in the US, while NKE is also closing stores in multiple countries, including Canada, Western Europe, Australia and New Zealand. Walmart’s Sam’s Club is to temporarily adjust in club shopping hours.
  • Of note for US banks, (JPM, BAC, BK, C, GS, STT, WFC, USB) those listed have all announced the suspension of its share repurchase programme through Q2 20.

16th March 2020

  • US equity futures hit limit down in wake of the Federal Reserve who cut rates by 100bps and launched USD 700bln of QE, while it agreed to lower pricing on standing US Dollar liquidity swaps with major global central banks by 25bps. The emergency announcement spurred further panic across markets and participants are now looking for any further measures from the fiscal side.
  • This week’s Barron’s articles highlight the situation for airlines could perhaps get even worse this week amid COVID-19 while Valero (VLO), Concho (CXO) and Cabot Oil & Gas (COG) could still prosper amid the fall in oil prices.
  • Of note for US banks, (JPM, BAC, BK, C, GS, STT, WFC, USB) those listed have all announced the suspension of its share repurchase programme through Q2 20.
  • Of note for Casino names (WYNN, MGM, PENN, ERI, BYD), all listed announced a closure of certain resorts in various locations, particularly: Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Michigan. MGM to close Northfield and Springfield parks, Penn National Gaming & Boyd Gaming to suspend its operations at its Ohio, Indiana and Illinois casinos, and Penn’s Plainridge park casino. Wynn is to temporarily close its Las Vegas resort. Eldorado’s Grand Victoria Casino, Tropicana Casino and Scioto Downs, in Illinios, Indiana and Ohio, have also temporarily closed.
  • Of note for Cruise names (RCL, CCL, NCLH) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines), RCL has become the latest operator to suspend its global cruise operations. Meanwhile, CCL announced effectively immediately a halt of its service across its US fleet and will resume on April 10th.
  • Of note for Airlines (LUV, DAL, UAL), operators are preparing for further flight reductions after US President Trump announced the travel ban has been extended to the UK and Ireland. Meanwhile, LUV announced it is seriously considering reducing flights in the short term and United Airlines (UAL) announced it is now expecting March revenue to be down USD 1.5bln Y/Y.
  • Of note for Retailers (UAA, NKE, ANF, WMT, GPS, LULU) all announced they are to temporarily close stores in the US, while NKE is also closing stores in multiple countries, including Canada, Western Europe, Australia and New Zealand. Walmart’s Sam’s Club is to temporarily adjust in club shopping hours.
  • Of note for Energy names (XLE, XOM, CVX), Saudi Aramco net profit for 2019 -21%, expects CapEx in 2020 to be between USD 25-30bln in light of current market conditions, noting future CapEx is currently under review. Paid dividends of USD 73.2bln in 2019, intends to declare 2020 cash dividend of USD 75bln.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has been fined EUR 1.2bln by French authorities over anti-competitive behaviour. Elsewhere it has closed all stores outside of China for 14 days.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) / Southwest Airlines (LUV) (Industrials/Airlines) – FAA is reportedly considering enhanced inspections on Boeing 737 jets following an inflight incident on a Southwestern plane which saw a 12-inch rupture in the aluminium skin of a Southwest Airlines plane.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) co-founder Bill Gates stepped down from the company’s board of directors to focus on his philanthropic priorities. Gates also stepped down from Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) (Financials/Multi-Sector Holdings) board.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) announced it is to make Frozen 2 available on Disney + three months ahead of the planned schedule and will start on March 15th.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has reportedly been sharing data between services without consent, breaching European Data protection law by an Irish regulator, according to FT.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) announced it has seen an increase in people shopping online, noting it is currently out of stock on some household staples.
  • American Airlines Group (AAL) (Industrials/Airlines) will reportedly cut its long-haul international flights by 75% due to the fall in demand and government restrictions.
  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) announced it is to draw down USD 2.5bln through its revolving credit facility.
  • Monster Beverage (MNST) (Consumer Staples/Soft Drinks) authorised a new USD 500mln share repurchase programme.
  • Netflix Inc. (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) and Disney (DIS) have reportedly halted productions due to the coronavirus outbreak, according to The Verge.

S&P 500

  • CIGNA Corp. (CI) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) announced it is taking several steps to further its commitment to customers, clients and communities and will cover the test with no cost sharing when recommended by a health official, and CI will waive costs for customers who paid personally in a relation to COVID-19 tests.
  • Delta Air Lines Inc. (DAL) (Industrials/Airlines) announced it reached an agreement with management on the coronavirus.
  • Lilly (Eli) & Co. (LLY) and Incyte (INCY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) received breakthrough FDA therapy designation for its alopecia areata treatment, baricitinib. Elsewhere, its CEO hopes to have a clinical trial for its coronavirus vaccine to take place in the Summer.
  • Lockheed Martin Corp. (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) board of directors named its new CEO as James Taiclet, succeeding Marillyn Hewson as of June 15th. James Taiclet will remain on the board, which he joined in 2018, and has served as Chairman, CEO and President of American Tower (AMT) since 2004.
  • Macerich (MAC) (Real Estate/Retail REITs) reduced its quarterly dividend to USD 0.50/shr (Prev. USD 0.75/shr), announce it is to be paid 20% in cash and 80% in stock.
  • The Mosaic Company (MOS) (Materials/Fertilizers & Agricultural Chemicals) Sales update (Feb.): Potash 489k tonnes (Prev. 632k tonnes Y/Y), sales revenues USD 118mln (prev. 161mln Y/Y). Fertiliser sales 737k tonnes (Prev. 512k tonnes Y/Y), sales revenue USD 255mln (Prev. 245mln). Phosphates 532k tonnes (Prev. 458k tonnes), sales revenue USD 172mln (prev. 221mln)
  • Under Armour Class A (UAA) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) is to close all of its stores in North America, from March 16th to March 28th.

OTHER

  • Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) announced it has withdrawn its Q120 and FY20 guidance, while also shutting its stores outside the APAC region until March 28th.
  • EQT Corp (EQT) (Energy, Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) lowers its 2020 capital expenditure guidance by USD 75mln and has executed an agreement to permanently release firm transportation and permanently release firm transportation and provides on debt repayment, adj. FCF expected to be between USD 25-325mln. FY20 adj. EBITDA view between USD 1.475-1.575bln, CapEx 1.075-1.175bln, adj. operating cash flow 1.325-1.425bln.
  • Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) announced its Maserati will temporarily suspend production in the European Union, while its operations in Italy have been suspended.
  • Taiwan Semiconductor (TSMC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) is reportedly mulling a new plant in the US after facing pressure from Washington, according to Nikkei.

US HHS Department has reportedly been hit by a cyber attack last night
Italian government to grant Alitalia a further EUR 600mln in 2020 to stay afloat amid COVID-19

analysis_details: • This was touted at over last week by Politico citing sources

subject: Brazilian Central Bank says an estimated BRL 3.2trln of loans eligible to benefit from new relaxed terms, depending on take up; to expand ability of banks to use their capital to back up relaxed loan terms and maintain credit flow
content:
• Lower capital requirements for banks to free up BRL 56bln, allowing banks to raise credit by BRL 637bln
  • Together with recent reserve requirement reduction, new measures will raise liquidity across the country's financial system by BRL 135bln
  • USD 360bln international reserves is also a cushion to make sure liquidity and smooth functioning of the FX market 
  • Has a wide range of instruments that can be used if required to ensure financial stability and support the economy

subject: US Secretary of State Pompeo urges Iraq's PM to defend coalition personnel supporting efforts to defeat ISIS; will take additional action as necessary in self defense if attacked
German Transport Ministry stops flights from Iran and China due, according to Bild
Saudi Aramco CFO says financial flexibility retained for further action
White House Trade Advisor Navarro has asked Congress to consider payroll tax cut through 2020-end, bringing Executive Order to US President Trump on supply chain, CNBC
Brazil's National monetary council has approved emergency measures to shield the economy from the impact from COVID-19; companies and households in good financial shape will renegotiate loans

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and other senior administration officials were meeting throughout the weekend to prepare the next round of proposals, which Politico says "we should hear about soon", via Politico MM

Sanofi (SAN FP)/ Regeneron (REGN) - Cos are to begin global Kevzara trials for patients with severe coronavirus, US Phase II/III trials initiated and will begin enrolling patients immediately, US based trials will begin at medical centers in NY

IMF says it is ready to mobilize USD 1trln loan capacity to fight COVID-19; fiscal stimulus will be necessary to prevent long-lasting economic damage, such as raised paid sick leave and targeted tax relief
content:
• Has received interest from about 20 more countries for ongoing loan programmes, in addition to 40 existing prorammes totaling USD 200bln
  • Central bank swap lines to EM countries could be needed
  • Forex interventions and capital flow management measures can usefully complement monetary policy actions
  • Banks should use their capital and liquidity buffers as well as renegotiate loan terms for stressed borrowers
  • The Catastrophe Containment and Relief Trust for the poorest countries has about USD 400mln available for potential debt relief, looking to raise it to USD 1bln

EU Commission says EU Executive Chief is to partake in G7 conference call at 14:00 GMT
US Surgeon General says US may need between 6-8 weeks to get over the worst
China says imported COVID-19 cases bring uncertainties to the end of the outbreak, according to state media
UK PM Johnson spokesperson says the PM also spoke to the BoE Governor Bailey; will discuss the latest developments in global markets and coordinated action overnight with Bailey and the Chancellor

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 16th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • FOMC cut the Fed Funds Rate 100bps to 0.00%-0.25% and launched a USD 700bln QE program
  • RBNZ lowered the OCR by 75bps to 0.25% in an emergency meeting and stated that the OCR is to remain at 0.25% for at least a year
  • BoJ held an emergency monetary policy meeting in which it kept short-term rates at -0.10% and maintained long-term yield target at 0%, but raised purchases of ETFs and J-REITs
  • European equities continue to erode in early trade [Euro Stoxx 50 -8.5%], US equity futures are locked in limit down
  • In FX, DXY is softer, USD/JPY retreated below 106.00, CAD, NZD and AUD concede ground to the Buck
  • Looking ahead highlights include US NY Fed Manufacturing, Eurogroup meeting

CENTRAL BANKS

FOMC cut the Fed Funds Rate 100bps to 0.00%-0.25% via 9-1 vote (Mester dissented preferring a 50bps cut) and the Fed launched USD 700bln QE program in which it will increase Treasury purchases by at least USD 500bln and raise MBS purchases by USD 200bln. Fed expects target interest rates will remain in this range until economy has weathered recent events and is on track to meet inflation and employment targets, while it is reducing requirement ratio to 0% effective March 26th. (Newswires)

Fed Chair Powell said the coronavirus is having a profound effect on US and globally, while he added that weakness abroad will weigh on US exports for a while and that financial conditions in US tightened markedly. Powell also stated that today's actions will help the US economy as well as promote a more vigorous return to normal, and that the emergency FOMC meeting was in lieu of meeting on March 17th-18th. Furthermore, Powell the Fed doesn't see negative rates as appropriate policy response in the US and he is willing to be patient in assessing when to raise rates back from near-zero, while he suggested the Fed has plenty of policy space and that fiscal policy should also play a major role. (Newswires)

BoE Governor Carney said Fed, BoJ, Bank of Canada, ECB and SNB have agreed to lower pricing on standing US Dollar liquidity swaps by 25bps and that central banks will offer US Dollar swaps with 84-day maturities in addition to 1-week operations, while he added that the actions will ease strains in global funding markets. (Newswires)

RBA said it is to conduct 1-month and 3-month operations until further notice, while it will conduct 6-month operations or longer at least weekly. Furthermore, the RBA later said it added AUD 5.9bln to banking system through market repo operations, while it is ready to purchase Australia government bonds and will announce further policy steps on Thursday. (Newswires)

RBNZ lowered the OCR by 75bps to 0.25% in an emergency meeting and stated that the OCR is to remain at 0.25% for at least a year, while it delayed higher capital requirements for banks and stated that if more stimulus is required, the preference is large scale government bond purchases instead of another rate cut. There were also comments from RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby that the rate cut and other measures announced give bank sufficient time to reassess the situation and that stopping at 0.25% signals RBNZ are not looking to go to zero or negative rates, while RBNZ Chief Economist Young Ha said bond purchase program is to be ready for May if needed. (Newswires)

BoJ held an emergency monetary policy meeting in which it kept short-term rates at -0.10% and maintained long-term yield target at 0%, but raised purchases of ETFs to JPY 12tln from JPY 6tln and increased purchases of J-REITS to JPY 180bln from JPY 90bln, while it set aside JPY 2tln for more buying of commercial paper and corporate bonds. Furthermore, the decision on QQE with yield curve control was made by 7-2 vote with Kataoka and Harada the dissenters again, while the central bank stated it is ready to ease further without hesitation as needed with a close eye on coronavirus. BoJ announced additional JPY 100bln JGB purcahses in 3-5yr and 5-10yr maturities on March 17th. (Newswires)

HKMA lowered its base rate by 64bps to 0.86% and announced that the countercyclical buffer is to be lowered to 1% from 2% with immediate effect. (Newswires)

BoK cuts key base rate by 50bps to 0.75% in an emergency move. (Newswires)

German State of Bavaria is making available up to EUR 10bln of special funds due to coronavirus. (Newswires)

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US House voted 363-40 to pass bill to make coronavirus testing free and require paid sick leave for those impacted by the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

New York City Mayor De Blasio ordered restaurants, bars, nightlife and cinemas to shut except for delivery and the Los Angeles Mayor also ordered the close of restaurants, bars and nightclubs in an effort to contain spread of coronavirus. Elsewhere, Washington Governor Inslee said will sign state-wide emergency proclamation to temporary shut-down restaurants, bars, entertainment and recreational facilities, although restaurants will be allowed to provide take-out and delivery, while the ban will not apply to grocery stores nor pharmacies. (Newswires) US CDC recommends all gathering of over 50 people be suspended. (Newswires)

New Zealand PM Ardern said business continuity package which will be announced on Tuesday will be significant. PM Ardern also stated the focus is on jobs and that this is phase 1 of the response, while she added that the impact of virus could be greater than the global financial crisis. (Newswires)

Mainland China reported 16 additional cases of coronavirus and 14 additional deaths on March 15th vs. Prev. 20 additional cases and 10 additional deaths on March 14th. In other news, South Korea coronavirus cases increased by 74 to a total of 8236, while there were 303 additional recovered patients and there were no additional deaths reported for the first time since Feb. 15th. (Newswires/Yonhap)

UK Government is to make further announcements on coronavirus measures later today, according to PM's Senior Advisor Cummings. (Newswires)

Italy’s coronavirus cases rose to 24747 from 21157 and there were 368 new deaths to bring the total death toll to 1809. (Newswires)

France and Spain banned all non-essential activities and Paris warned as much as 70% of the population would be infected by the coronavirus, while Germany is to impose temporary controls on its borders with France, Switzerland, Austria, Denmark and Luxembourg on Monday to contain the spread of the coronavirus. (Times/BBC) French President Macron is to address French nation at 1900GMT today. (Newswires)

EU Council President Michel is to conduct a video call with EU leaders tomorrow to discuss coronavirus. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets weakened and US equity futures hit limit down to start the week as coronavirus fears and disruptions continued to spook investor sentiment, despite numerous policy measures to address the fallout from the outbreak including the Fed throwing the kitchen sink with a 100bps emergency cut and USD 700bln QE announcement. This followed the national emergency declaration by US President Trump last Friday which opens access to USD 50bln of emergency funds for states to tackle the coronavirus, while BoC and RBNZ also recently announced emergency cuts of 50bps and 75bps respectively. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (-9.7%) failed to benefit from the global policy measures and announcement the RBA stands ready to purchase government bonds, with heavy losses in mining names, financials and industrials resulting the index’s worst ever drop, while Nikkei 225 (-2.6%) was choppy amid the BoJ’s emergency meeting in which it kept rates and the yield target unchanged but doubled ETF and J-REIT purchases. Hang Seng (-4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-3.4%) were both negative due to widespread fears and after surprise contractions to Chinese Industrial Production (-13.5% vs. Exp. 1.5%) and Retail Sales (-20.5% vs. Exp. 0.8%), but with losses in the mainland stemmed after the PBoC’s recent targeted RRR cuts of 50bps-100bps and additional 100bps cut for joint-stock banks which will unleash CNY 550bln of funds, while the HKMA authority also announced a rate cut in lock step with the Fed albeit to a lesser extent of just 64bps. Finally, 10yr JGBs opened lower due to the after-hours slump on Friday as stock markets found some firm but brief relief, although JGB prices rebounded off their lows as fears returned to the fore of investors’ minds before retreating again after the BoJ announced to keep main policy settings unchanged but instead boosted purchases of ETFs, J-REIT, Commercial Paper and Corporate Bonds, while pressure was also seen in the Australian 10yr yield after the RBA signalled a readiness to purchase government bonds.

PBoC conducted CNY 100bln in 1yr MLF operations at 3.15% vs. Prev. 3.15%. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0018 vs. Exp. 7.0067 (Prev. 7.0033)

Chinese Industrial Production (Feb) Y/Y -13.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 6.9%). (Newswires) Chinese Retail Sales (Feb) Y/Y -20.5% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 8.0%) Chinese House Prices (Feb) Y/Y 5.8% (Prev. 6.3%)

China stats bureau said China's economy remains resilient despite coronavirus impact, while it expects the economy to show significant improvement in March and sees the impact to economy from coronavirus to decrease in Q2. (Newswires)

US

Apple (AAPL) - Co. has closed all stores outside of Greater China for two weeks in a bid to contain the virus outbreak. Separetely, Co. has been fined EUR 1.1bln by the French anti-trust agency (Newswires) Co. has ~12.0% weighting in the Nasdaq, ~8.0% in DJIA and ~5.0% in S&P500

Other US closures - Lululemon (LULU) is to also close all North America and Europe stores from March 16th-27th, while MGM (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) are to temporary close their Las Vegas properties due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Russian Foreign Ministry says militants in Syria's Idlib are not complying with the ceasefire agreement, according to IFAX. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities continue to erode in early trade [Euro Stoxx 50 -8.5%] despite pre-emptive monetary easing measures from global Central Banks including a 1ppt reduction by the Fed alongside a USD 700bln QE boost. The downbeat sentiment from the APAC session reverberated into Europe as the underlying coronavirus theme further crystallises, which saw US equity futures hit the 5% limit down at the open and hover at the levels during European trade thus far (Full details available here). Meanwhile, Euronext stated that it will be doubling the ETF threshold amid “exceptional market conditions caused by recent news and events”, with the normal threshold set to return once condition return back to normal. Sector-wise, the usual suspects show underperformance – Financials (-9.6%) sink as banks bear the brunt of the lower yield environment, whilst Consumer Discretionary (-9.3%) follow closely amid a further deterioration in Travel & Leisure (-18.0%) in light of renewed fleet groundings in airline and cruise names. On that front, Air France-KLM (-16.7%) remains a laggard in the Stoxx 600 after noting that flight activity will be reduced significantly over the next few days, with the number of seats available per km seen dropping between 70-90%. easyJet (-21.0%) meanwhile stated that it has taken on further cancellations, with these actions to continue for the foreseeable future. Tui (-30.0%) plumbed the depths following after withdrawing its FY20 guidance and applying for state aid to support the business. Credit Suisse (-12.0%) shares feel extra pressure after US prosecutors are pursuing the Co. for its role in a USD 2bln Mozambieq corruption case, in which they believe that they have enough evidence against the Co. Elsewhere, Associated British Foods saw considerable downside in early European trade despite a rosier trading update (sees adj. operating profit ahead of prior guidance), with some attributing the move to a fat-finger. Finally, Bayer (-4.7%) outperforms the German index but conforms to the overall sell-off despite source reports that the Co. is a step closer in agreeing to draft settlement regarding tens of thousands Roundup weed killer claims.

FX

USD - The Greenback has handed back almost all Friday’s gains and would surely be even weaker if the non-US Dollars were not underperforming on a combination of rate cuts and risk aversion. Indeed, the DXY is only just off its pre-weekend low of 97.335 within a 97.446-98.473 range after the Fed’s latest intermeeting policy action (-100 bp FF cut to 0-0.25% and Usd700 bn QE) as the US Treasury curve unwinds some of its initial bull-steepening.

CAD/NZD/AUD - As noted above, the Loonie, Kiwi and Aussie are all conceding ground to their US counterpart in wake of various forms of stimulus designed to protect respective economies from further COVID-19 contagion, including a standard 50 bp BoC rate cut (on top of the ½ point reduction at the scheduled March meeting), -75 bp from the RBNZ and the RBA introducing more repos ahead of additional ‘measures’ to come on Thursday that may involve some for of asset purchases. Usd/Cad is back up near 1.3900, Nzd/Usd is straddling 0.6000 within a wide 0.6153-0.5945 band and Aud/Usd is hovering around 0.6170 between 0.6303-0.6097 parameters, with the latter also taking on board extremely bleak Chinese data (ip and retail sales) that is keeping Usd/CNH afloat on the 7.0000 handle.

JPY/CHF/EUR - It’s abundantly evident that safe-haven appeal is considerably stronger than any negativity associated with looser monetary policy or the prospect in the case of the Yen and Franc that have both strengthened vs the Buck and generally. Usd/Jpy has retreated through 106.00 from almost 108.00, while Usd/Chf has tested 0.9400, with Eur/Jpy and Eur/Chf eyeing 118.00 and sub-1.0550 respectively even though the single currency is outpacing the Usd either side of 1.1200. To recap, the BoJ joined others in the fight against nCoV via increased QE, while the clock is ticking down to the SNB’s quarterly policy review this Thursday and latest weekly Swiss sight deposits suggest more intervention. For its part, ECB’s Holzmann has reiterated that the GC is willing to do more after last week’s targeted measures.

SCANDI/EM - As usual when oil and other commodities (Gold also) succumb to broad and severe risk-off positioning, the Nok, Rub, Mxn and Zar tend to get hit harder than most and today is no exception, albeit with crude prices not quite experiencing the near panic selling/liquidation seen this time last week. However, many regional currencies are at fresh record or multi-year lows and only being propped by intervention, like the Ils to name just one. 

FIXED INCOME

In stark contrast to last Monday, bonds are markedly mixed with the Eurozone debt futures all under pressure and not seeing any real safe-haven flight in contrast to Gilts that are holding above parity and 136.00, albeit off 136.24 at best, and USTs maintaining a firm underlying bid, but again some distance from overnight session highs forged on the Fed’s much more aggressive policy moves late last Friday. Ahead, NY Fed manufacturing to provide some, passing diversion from the ongoing coronavirus vigil.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures continue to deteriorate amid further materialisation in coronavirus woes, and with further cancellations in the Travel and Leisure sector dampening demand growth in the complex. WTI Apr’20 dipped below USD 30/bbl at the open of electronic trade before taking multiple stabs at the level to the downside since Europe entered the market, although giving up the handle at the time of writing. Meanwhile, Brent May’20 underperforms its US counterpart with the prospect of the OPEC breakdown further weighing on the contract - Brent gapped lower to sub-40/bbl vs. Friday’s close of ~USD 45/bbl. Analysts at ING state that the underperformance doesn’t come as too much of a surprise “given the severity of the breakout across Europe, along with the action taken by governments to try to contain the virus”. The Dutch bank also suggests that the current weakness in oil prices is likely to persist through Q2 this year as the surge in supply and demand hit means that the markets will likely see a significant surplus. Elsewhere, spot gold (-1.8%) trades weaker as investors flee for cash holdings amid significant losses in riskier assets, traders also note that a decline below USD 1500/oz may induce a stop-chase, with the yellow metal’s 200DMA ~1500.25/oz and a Fib level at USD 1495.96/oz. On that front, spot silver (-10.7%) slid since the open and briefly fell south of USD 13/oz to levels last seen in 2009. Similarly, the flight to cash and a significant slump in Chinese IP figures have prompted copper prices to crash from ~USD 2.55/lb to sub USD 2.40/lb.

OPEC/OPEC+ JTC meeting planned for March 18th in Vienna has been cancelled, sources state. (Newswires)

content: Another manic start to the week for UK bonds, but this time far from one way traffic as the 10 year debt future returned to Liffe below parity and extended losses to 44 ticks at 135.45 in line with Eurozone counterparts before rebounding firmly to 136.21 more in keeping with the underlying bid in US Treasuries. Conversely, 3 month contracts resumed higher and have remained bid between 2.5 and 7 ticks above last Friday’s settlement levels in catch up trade following the latest spate of global Central Bank rate cuts and unconventional stimulus that will underpin expectations for more from the BoE at the March policy meeting if not before.

content: The 10 year German benchmark has retreated further from highs posted in wake of the Fed’s latest rate cut and fresh round of QE, at 175.25 vs last Friday’s 174.17 close, eyeing the EU cash bourse opens and Eurozone counterparts that are paring some losses. Bunds are now holding just above a 173.73 base as debt curves steepen and several Governments roll out more fiscal aid in a concerted attempt to mitigate the fallout from COVID-19. On that note, all eyes on today’s Eurogroup meeting and a G7 call.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

16th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets weakened and US equity futures hit limit down to start the week as coronavirus fears and disruptions continued to spook investor sentiment, despite numerous policy measures to address the fallout from the outbreak including the Fed throwing the kitchen sink with a 100bps emergency cut and USD 700bln QE announcement. This followed the national emergency declaration by US President Trump last Friday which opens access to USD 50bln of emergency funds for states to tackle the coronavirus, while BoC and RBNZ also recently announced emergency cuts of 50bps and 75bps respectively. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (-9.7%) failed to benefit from the global policy measures and announcement the RBA stands ready to purchase government bonds, with heavy losses in mining names, financials and industrials resulting the index’s worst ever drop, while Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) was choppy amid the BoJ’s emergency meeting in which it kept rates and the yield target unchanged but doubled ETF and J-REIT purchases. Hang Seng (-3.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) were both negative due to widespread fears and after surprise contractions to Chinese Industrial Production (-13.5% vs. Exp. 1.5%) and Retail Sales (-20.5% vs. Exp. 0.8%), but with losses in the mainland stemmed after the PBoC’s recent targeted RRR cuts of 50bps-100bps and additional 100bps cut for joint-stock banks which will unleash CNY 550bln of funds, while the HKMA authority also announced a rate cut in lock step with the Fed albeit to a lesser extent of just 64bps

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 16th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·       FOMC cut the Fed Funds Rate 100bps to 0.00%-0.25% and launched a USD 700bln QE program

·       Bank of Canada cut its key overnight interest rate by 50bps to 0.75% from 1.25% and stands ready to adjust monetary policy further if required

·       RBNZ lowered the OCR by 75bps to 0.25% in an emergency meeting and stated that the OCR is to remain at 0.25% for at least a year

·       BoJ held an emergency monetary policy meeting in which it kept short-term rates at -0.10% and maintained long-term yield target at 0%, but raised purchases of ETFs and J-REITs

·       US President Trump declared a national emergency over the coronavirus which opens up access to USD 50bln for states and localities to fight against the coronavirus

·       Asian equity markets weakened and US equity futures hit limit down as coronavirus fears and disruptions continued to spook investor sentiment despite central bank support

·       DXY briefly dropped below 98.00 after the Fed rate cut, before being granted some reprieve

·       Looking ahead, highlights include US NY Fed Manufacturing, Eurogroup meeting

 

16th March 2020 

·       FOMC cut the Fed Funds Rate 100bps to 0.00%-0.25% and launched a USD 700bln QE program

·       Bank of Canada cut its key overnight interest rate by 50bps to 0.75% from 1.25% and stands ready to adjust monetary policy further if required

·       RBNZ lowered the OCR by 75bps to 0.25% in an emergency meeting and stated that the OCR is to remain at 0.25% for at least a year

·       BoJ held an emergency monetary policy meeting in which it kept short-term rates at -0.10% and maintained long-term yield target at 0%, but raised purchases of ETFs and J-REITs

·       US President Trump declared a national emergency over the coronavirus which opens up access to USD 50bln for states and localities to fight against the coronavirus

·       Asian equity markets weakened and US equity futures hit limit down as coronavirus fears and disruptions continued to spook investor sentiment despite central bank support

·       DXY briefly dropped below 98.00 after the Fed rate cut, before being granted some reprieve

·       Looking ahead, highlights include US NY Fed Manufacturing, Eurogroup meeting

 

CENTRAL BANKS 

FOMC cut the Fed Funds Rate 100bps to 0.00%-0.25% via 9-1 vote (Mester dissented preferring a 50bps cut) and the Fed launched USD 700bln QE program in which it will increase Treasury purchases by at least USD 500bln and raise MBS purchases by USD 200bln. Fed expects target interest rates will remain in this range until economy has weathered recent events and is on track to meet inflation and employment targets, while it is reducing requirement ratio to 0% effective March 26th. (Newswires)

Fed Chair Powell said the coronavirus is having a profound effect on US and globally, while he added that weakness abroad will weigh on US exports for a while and that financial conditions in US tightened markedly. Powell also stated that today's actions will help the US economy as well as promote a more vigorous return to normal, and that the emergency FOMC meeting was in lieu of meeting on March 17th-18th. Furthermore, Powell the Fed doesn't see negative rates as appropriate policy response in the US and he is willing to be patient in assessing when to raise rates back from near-zero, while he suggested the Fed has plenty of policy space and that fiscal policy should also play a major role. (Newswires)

Bank of Canada cut key overnight interest rate by 50bps to 0.75% from 1.25% and stands ready to adjust monetary policy further if required to support economic growth and keep inflation on target. BoC said it is a proactive measure taken in light of the negative shocks to Canada's economy arising from the COVID-19 pandemic and recent sharp drop in oil prices, while it added that it has taken measures to ensure banks have sufficient liquidity and have a variety of other tools in the tool kit to address the crisis. In other news, Canada's Chief Financial Superintendent said they are lowering the domestic stability buffer requirement for major banks to 1.25% from 2.50% of risk-weighted assets to add an additional CAD 300bln in lending capacity. (Newswires)

RBA said it is to conduct 1-month and 3-month operations until further notice, while it will conduct 6-month operations or longer at least weekly. Furthermore, the RBA later said it added AUD 5.9bln to banking system through market repo operations, while it is ready to purchase Australia government bonds and will announce further policy steps on Thursday. (Newswires)

RBNZ lowered the OCR by 75bps to 0.25% in an emergency meeting and stated that the OCR is to remain at 0.25% for at least a year, while it delayed higher capital requirements for banks and stated that if more stimulus is required, the preference is large scale government bond purchases instead of another rate cut. There were also comments from RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby that the rate cut and other measures announced give bank sufficient time to reassess the situation and that stopping at 0.25% signals RBNZ are not looking to go to zero or negative rates, while RBNZ Chief Economist Young Ha said bond purchase program is to be ready for May if needed. (Newswires)

BoJ held an emergency monetary policy meeting in which it kept short-term rates at -0.10% and maintained long-term yield target at 0%, but raised purchases of ETFs to JPY 12tln from JPY 6tln and increased purchases of J-REITS to JPY 180bln from JPY 90bln, while it set aside JPY 2tln for more buying of commercial paper and corporate bonds. Furthermore, the decision on QQE with yield curve control was made by 7-2 vote with Kataoka and Harada the dissenters again, while the central bank stated it is ready to ease further without hesitation as needed with a close eye on coronavirus.

HKMA lowered its base rate by 64bps to 0.86% and announced that the countercyclical buffer is to be lowered to 1% from 2% with immediate effect. (Newswires)

 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US President Trump declared a national emergency over the coronavirus which opens up access to USD 50bln for states and localities to fight against the coronavirus, while he announced to ‘waive' interest payments on all federal government loans including student loans. Furthermore, Trump also stated the UK will be added to the travel ban list in the future as cases grow, while he stated that market will be thrilled by the Fed rate cut and suggested to take it easy on panic grocery buying as grocery stores will work 24 hours around the clock to keep stores stocked. (Newswires)

US House voted 363-40 to pass bill to make coronavirus testing free and require paid sick leave for those impacted by the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

New York City Mayor De Blasio ordered restaurants, bars, nightlife and cinemas to shut except for delivery and the Los Angeles Mayor also ordered the close of restaurants, bars and nightclubs in an effort to contain spread of coronavirus. Elsewhere, Washington Governor Inslee said will sign state-wide emergency proclamation to temporary shut-down restaurants, bars, entertainment and recreational facilities, although restaurants will be allowed to provide take-out and delivery, while the ban will not apply to grocery stores nor pharmacies. (Newswires) US CDC recommends all gathering of over 50 people be suspended. (Newswires)

 

New Zealand PM Ardern said business continuity package which will be announced on Tuesday will be significant. PM Ardern also stated the focus is on jobs and that this is phase 1 of the response, while she added that the impact of virus could be greater than the global financial crisis. (Newswires)

 

Mainland China reported 16 additional cases of coronavirus and 14 additional deaths on March 15th vs. Prev. 20 additional cases and 10 additional deaths on March 14th. In other news, South Korea coronavirus cases increased by 74 to a total of 8236, while there were 303 additional recovered patients and there were no additional deaths reported for the first time since Feb. 15th. (Newswires/Yonhap)

 

Italy’s coronavirus cases rose to 24747 from 21157 and there were 368 new deaths to bring the total death toll to 1809. (Newswires)

 

France and Spain banned all non-essential activities and Paris warned as much as 70% of the population would be infected by the coronavirus, while Germany is to impose temporary controls on its borders with France, Switzerland, Austria, Denmark and Luxembourg on Monday to contain the spread of the coronavirus. (Times/BBC)

 

Apple (AAPL) shutdown all stores globally outside of mainland China for the next 2 weeks as a measure to tackle the coronavirus outbreak and Lululemon (LULU) is to also close all North America and Europe stores from March 16th-27th, while MGM (MGM) and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) are to temporary close their Las Vegas properties due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia equity markets weakened and US equity futures hit limit down to start the week as coronavirus fears and disruptions continued to spook investor sentiment, despite numerous policy measures to address the fallout from the outbreak including the Fed throwing the kitchen sink with a 100bps emergency cut and USD 700bln QE announcement. This followed the national emergency declaration by US President Trump last Friday which opens access to USD 50bln of emergency funds for states to tackle the coronavirus, while BoC and RBNZ also recently announced emergency cuts of 50bps and 75bps respectively. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (-9.7%) failed to benefit from the global policy measures and announcement the RBA stands ready to purchase government bonds, with heavy losses in mining names, financials and industrials resulting the index’s worst ever drop, while Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) was choppy amid the BoJ’s emergency meeting in which it kept rates and the yield target unchanged but doubled ETF and J-REIT purchases. Hang Seng (-3.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) were both negative due to widespread fears and after surprise contractions to Chinese Industrial Production (-13.5% vs. Exp. 1.5%) and Retail Sales (-20.5% vs. Exp. 0.8%), but with losses in the mainland stemmed after the PBoC’s recent targeted RRR cuts of 50bps-100bps and additional 100bps cut for joint-stock banks which will unleash CNY 550bln of funds, while the HKMA authority also announced a rate cut in lock step with the Fed albeit to a lesser extent of just 64bps. Finally, 10yr JGBs opened lower due to the after-hours slump on Friday as stock markets found some firm but brief relief, although JGB prices rebounded off their lows as fears returned to the fore of investors’ minds before retreating again after the BoJ announced to keep main policy settings unchanged but instead boosted purchases of ETFs, J-REIT, Commercial Paper and Corporate Bonds, while pressure was also seen in the Australian 10yr yield after the RBA signalled a readiness to purchase government bonds.

PBoC conducted CNY 100bln in 1yr MLF operations at 3.15% vs. Prev. 3.15%. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0018 vs. Exp. 7.0067 (Prev. 7.0033)

Chinese Industrial Production (Feb) Y/Y -13.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 6.9%). (Newswires) Chinese Retail Sales (Feb) Y/Y -20.5% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 8.0%) Chinese House Prices (Feb) Y/Y 5.8% (Prev. 6.3%)

China stats bureau said China's economy remains resilient despite coronavirus impact, while it expects the economy to show significant improvement in March and sees the impact to economy from coronavirus to decrease in Q2. (Newswires)

UK/EU

BoE Governor Carney said Fed, BoJ, Bank of Canada, ECB and SNB have agreed to lower pricing on standing US Dollar liquidity swaps by 25bps and that central banks will offer US Dollar swaps with 84-day maturities in addition to 1-week operations, while he added that the actions will ease strains in global funding markets. (Newswires)

UK Government is to hold daily televised press conferences to update the public about the virus outbreak, according to Downing Street. The media briefing later today will be followed by another Cobra committee meeting. (BBC) Furthermore, over 10k British soldiers, sailors and airmen could be put on standby in the coming weeks amid the worsening outbreak. Officials have reportedly been drawing up plans for a few weeks and are now ready to submit proposals to the PM. (Sky News) Meanwhile, a Public Health England briefing for senior NHS officials revealed that the epidemic in the UK will last until next spring and could lead to 7.9mln people being hospitalised. (Guardian)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Mar) M/M 1.0% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires) UK Rightmove House Prices (Mar) Y/Y 3.5% (Prev. 2.9%)

FX

DXY briefly dropped below 98.00 after the Fed’s 100bps emergency rate cut and QE announcement in which it will increase Treasury purchases by at least USD 500bln and MBS purchases by USD 200bln, with the Fed expecting target interest rates to remain in this range until the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to meet inflation and employment targets. Furthermore, Fed Chair Powell commented during the conference call that the Fed doesn't see negative rates as an appropriate policy response in the US but suggested the Fed has plenty of policy space and that fiscal policy should also play a major role. The Fed’s move to the zero-lower bound briefly underpinned the greenback’s major counterparts although the upside in EUR/USD proved to be short-lived after hitting resistance at the 1.1200 handle and with both Spain and France joining the bloc’s widening lockdown, while the upside in GBP/USD also stalled after failing to breach 1.2400. Elsewhere, the risk averse flows saw USD/JPY attempted a breakdown of the 106.00 level where support eventually held as markets await the conclusion of the BoJ’s emergency meeting which was later perceived as somewhat of a disappointment, and antipodeans were lacklustre due to their high-beta statuses and following the abysmal Chinese data releases, as well as the RBNZ’s 75bps emergency rate cut and RBA signalling it is prepared to conduct government bond purchases. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly lacklustre in which WTI crude futures briefly slipped to below the USD 30/bbl level despite the Fed’s efforts to contain the fallout from the coronavirus outbreak with an emergency 100bps cut and USD 700bln of QE, as the drastic measures and increased global shutdowns/lockdown stoked market disarray, and although there were recent reports President Trump asked the energy department to purchase oil through the SPR amid current  low price environment, Goldman Sachs remained cynical on the effects this would have to stem the risks of further weakness. Elsewhere, gold only saw limited gains despite the risk averse tone and weaker greenback following the Fed’s 100bps cut and QE announcement, while copper deteriorated in tandem with the broad risk-aversion.  

US President Trump asked the energy department to purchase oil through for the SPR and said they will it "will fill it to the top”. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs said SPR purchases could raise equilibrium price where global oil market rebalances by USD 2/bbl, but added that SPR purchases could be insufficient to reverse increasingly likely risk prices decline beneath Q2-Q3 USD 30/bbl Brent forecast to cash costs. (Newswires)

 

US 

The TPLEX bear steepened again on Friday amid a renewed risk appetite. The Treasury selling coincided with strength in equities, following on from Thursday where both were sold amid a flight to cash. It is possible that the move in government debt was less correlated to risk appetite and more to technical factors, such as the ongoing duration selling by risk parity-type players, as well as profit taking from exhausted levels, as has broadly been suggested in recent sessions. The TPLEX did find a bid after the NY Fed stepped into move forward its Treasury purchase schedule, although it ultimately proved short-lived, as the selling pressures resumed heading into settlement. The 10-year yield rose by around 9bps to just over 0.94%, while the 2-year yield remained unchanged at 0.48%. US T-note futures (H0) settled 1 point 3 ticks lower at 135-25+.

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said there is an agreement on the virus package and that he doesn’t anticipate the coronavirus pandemic to tip the economy into recession, while expects there will be a big rebound later in the year. (Newswires)
